comment_text: Gotta love the attempted smear of "is." It is only the verb of existence. The Woke project to make the sex of a person invisible is an offshoot. By the way, did you notice that Wokes want to steal the verb? Not just the pronoun, but the verb. Woke: "Dani just called, and they are on the way with the cupcakes. They said they are trying to not eat them all in the car."    Honest : "Dani just called, and they is on the way with the cupcakes. They said they is trying to not eat them all in the car."  NOTE: the verb in question is the verb of existence: "is." A thief is always attempting to cheat existence. They are greedy to forge their "truth" into reality for everyone.

Singular they is nonsense lol

Traditional examples of the so-called "singular they" are not in fact singular.  They were merely subtle semantic mismatches between plural pronouns and technically singular antecedents (which are usually conceptually plural, like "anyone" or "everone").   By analogy, one can imagine a person saying: "When one of us next goes to the post office, we should pick up the package waiting there."   I have no strong aversion to such semantic mismatches, but it is bizarre that you mock the 19th century gramarians for being averse to them, while at the same time relying on the rule they created requiring a match, to prove that the mismatched plural pronoun is really singular after all (because otherwise it would not match).  Also, I don't see what you are trying to prove with the discussion of "thou" and "you", and other lost forms.  We have lost many pronoun distinctions, and pronoun forms, and pronouns, but I don't see how it follows that we should lose another one.
Thank you! Im putting together a list of things like this (as a trans person) to help my mum understand.

I don't know if "you" serving for singular and plural second pronouns is helpful though.. The common usage of "you guys" or "y'all" shows that it's useful to have second-person pronouns that differentiate between the number of people I'm talking to.

If I am talking to two people and I ask them "Do you like Youtube?", I expect a response from both of them. But it may be confusing because "you" tends to be considered singular, so I may need to clarify that I expect answers from both of them by asking "Do you guys like Youtube?".

It gets more confusing if first I ask a question expecting a response from both of them, and then I ask a question to only one of them. "Do you like Youtube?" would be directed at both of them. If one responds yes and the other one responds no, I would ask only the one who responded no, "What do you like instead?". But if "you" changed from plural to singular, it's a bit hard to get that across. I have to make it super obvious with my eye contact and body language, but the language itself should suffice to make the distinction.
Thank you

This video is fantastic! Thank you!   I am a mathematics high school teacher and I was writing up a document for my class. I originally used he/she/his/her pronouns, but I wil now change it to they/their.   I was hoping you can help me with one of my sentences. The sentence is, ”The greater the number of people she attracts to purchase her magazine, the greater her revenue.”  I am changing it to,  “The greater the number of people they attract to purchase their magazine, the greater their revenue.”  The question I have is since I'm using they in the singular sense, should I instead write “The greater the number of people they attracts to purchase thier magazine…”? Thanks again for your work on educating us!!
I just wanted to see singular they in a sentence. Is it correct to say “They is going to the store”?
I feel like the word "you" is splitting. I hear ya when talking to friends or family (ex: how ya doing) and using the word you for other people.

This brings up the same problem I have with the current "you". Informally, we say stuff like "you guys" when referring to multiple people. If we want grammatically correct language to be as convenient as informal language, having the distinction between singular and plural is helpful. The only time "they" is more convenient is when used to talk about a person with an undefined gender, but every other time (if replacing he or she) would add ambiguity. "Brian did their homework" could mean he was doing someone else's homework. We already have a singular pronoun that is gender neutral "it" and if anything that should be replacing "he" or "she".

On the other hand. it cant be right to say "i dont know who they is, if you know for a fact that it is one person you are talking about right. it should always be they are even if it is a singular meaning
